column3: This is one of the things that has been 'fixed' so many times, can we please be sure it's okay this time?\n(change looks OK to me, though I don't think clearing twice is that bad, it can't hurt at least)

Yeah, so there is no 100% optimal solution for clearing memory, but please note that the goal of this PR is not to start this discussion about what the right method is. This merely fixes a weirdness on in the logic introduced by #11558.
Fine on changing the docs, but is it really necessary to remove the redundant `std::memset(ptr, 0, len)`.

Well, as you say, the call is redundant, so it's okay not to remove it but I'd argue it's desirable to remove it\n * for readability: It just looks wrong to do the same operation twice. I think people would complain about code that does `x = 0; x = 0;`.\n * for efficiency: While MSVC inlines the call to `SecureZeroMemory`, it is not clever enough to optimize the call to `memset` out, see https:/

Seeing the merge message this PR title is badly worded: yes, you can consider clearing the memory twice a logic error, but most people would consider it a logic error if it would result in *not clearing the memory*.\n\nSo to be 100% clear for anyone getting here: this is not a security fix.
